question: What are you trying to show?

options.question: Which scenario best describes your categorical comparison?
How many measures do you have?

options.description: If you have only one measure to compare across categories, a horizontal bar chart is often best. It handles long labels well.

options.question: What is the relationship between the measures?

options.description: If these 2–4 measures represent parts of a whole, show them in a stacked bar chart.

options.question: What is the goal of comparison?
Can these measures be expressed as a single variance or percentage?

options.result: Create the new metric - Bar Chart with Tooltips
options.description: Combine the measures into a single variance/percentage metric, then plot as a bar chart. Tooltips can reveal details on hover.
If each measure stands alone, use grouped bars to compare them side by side.
If the focus is on how these measures relate (e.g. correlation), consider a scatter plot.

options.question: Was it specifically requested to view all metrics together in one visual?

options.description: If you truly need to see many metrics in one place, a table with highlighting or color-coded cells can be more readable.

options.result: Rethink how this can be split up
options.description: Too many measures can overload a single chart. Consider smaller multiples, grouped dashboards, or summary vs. detail splits.

options.question: How many categories are you comparing?

options.description: If there's truly only one category, you may just show a single bar or number—there’s no real ‘comparison’ to do.

options.question: Are these categories hierarchical (i.e., parent-child)?
Can a drilldown be used?

options.description: Start at the parent level in a horizontal bar. Clicking a bar drills into child categories.

options.question: What is the nature of the comparison?
Do you have 5 or fewer categories per group?

options.description: Use grouped bars if you’re comparing up to ~5 subcategories side by side.
For many subcategories, a treemap or heatmap might be more efficient at showing everything at once.

options.question: Is this an absolute or relative comparison?

options.description: Stacked bars show each child’s absolute value contributing to the parent total.
100% stacking is better if you only care about proportions within each parent.
Use a heatmap to highlight patterns across multiple parent-child breakdowns.

options.question: What is the nature of the comparison?
Is the total number of items less than 20?

options.description: A grouped bar chart works well for comparing fewer items side by side.
For a larger set of categories, a heatmap can be more space-efficient.

options.question: Are there 5 or fewer components in the child category?

options.description: For a small set of subcategories, a 100% stacked bar is a quick read of proportions.
For many subcategories, a heatmap can show proportion variations more effectively.

options.question: What aspect of composition matters most?
How many components are you showing?
Are exact proportions important?

options.description: Use a 100% stacked bar chart. Add percentage labels. Consider horizontal orientation if labels are long.
Use a pie chart for a quick visual share of the whole. Order slices by size.

options.question: Can smaller components be grouped?

options.description: Group smaller slices as 'Other.'
Use a 100% stacked bar. Consider horizontal orientation for easier labeling.

options.question: Is hierarchy present in the data?

options.description: Use a treemap to show nested composition. Add interactive tooltips and drill-down.

options.question: Is interaction possible?

options.description: A scrollable/filterable bar chart can show top N by default, with details on demand.
Group items into major categories; consider 100% stacked bars for high-level composition.

options.question: How many time periods?
How many components?

options.description: Use two pie charts side by side. Keep consistent colors and slice order.
Use side-by-side 100% stacked bars. Consider a delta indicator.

options.question: How many components?

options.description: Use a 100% stacked area chart. Consider interactive tooltips.

options.question: Can components be grouped?

options.description: Aggregate smaller components into major categories, show in stacked area form.
One component per mini-chart. Good if you have many categories to compare over time.

options.question: How many hierarchy levels?
How many items at each level?

options.description: Use a sunburst chart. Provide interactive highlights or drill-down if possible.
Use a treemap. Add interactive drill-down and tooltips for deeper exploration.

options.question: Is interaction available?

options.description: Allow drill-down, search, and breadcrumb navigation to move through levels.
Show 2-3 levels in nested bars. Group minor categories or provide a separate detail view.

options.question: What aspect of the distribution are you focusing on?
Are you working with a small or large dataset?

options.description: Use a histogram to show how data is distributed across ranges.
considerations: For fewer data points, bins can be set manually for clarity.
Consider tooltips for exact bin counts or percentages.

options.description: Allows zooming, panning, or dynamic bin sizing for larger data volumes.
considerations: Add filters for segments (e.g., location, service type).
Hover to see exact bin or density values.

options.description: Show median, quartiles, and outliers for one or more groups.
considerations: Useful when comparing distributions across multiple groups.
Can color code or group by categories for clarity.

options.description: Displays distribution shape (density) plus outliers for each group.
considerations: Best used in exploratory dashboards (can be visually busy).
Ensure labeling clarifies what the ‘violin’ shape represents.

options.question: What type of relationship are you exploring?

options.description: Visualize how two measures correlate (e.g., satisfaction vs. staffing hours).
considerations: Optionally add a trend line or best-fit line.
Use tooltips to highlight outliers.

options.description: Show pairwise correlations across multiple metrics.
considerations: Color-coding helps identify strong/weak correlations.
Interactive filtering can isolate key metrics.

options.description: Ideal for exploring complex relationships (e.g., referral patterns).
considerations: Node size/color can reflect additional measures.
Clustering can reduce clutter in very large networks.

options.description: Compare multiple numeric variables in a matrix of scatter plots.
considerations: Can be overwhelming if too many variables are used.
Interactive brushing/highlighting helps reveal patterns.

options.question: What is your main focus over time?
Is the dataset small (few data points) or large (frequent data)?

options.description: Ideal for monthly or quarterly data to track changes in one metric over time.
considerations: Highlight significant events or milestones (e.g., policy changes).
Label key points if clarity is needed.

options.description: Allows users to navigate dense time series data (e.g., daily/hourly).
considerations: Hover tooltips help reveal exact values in crowded areas.
Consider weekly/monthly aggregation to prevent clutter.

options.text: Multiple metrics or comparisons over time
options.question: How many metrics do you want to track simultaneously?

options.description: Compare up to 3 trends in one chart (e.g., occupancy vs. satisfaction vs. staffing).
considerations: Use consistent or dual axes cautiously.
Add a clear legend or toggles to show/hide lines.

options.description: Each metric gets its own mini-chart for easier comparison.
considerations: Use a consistent scale across panels when possible.
Allows side-by-side scanning without clutter.

options.description: Useful for visualizing project milestones or resident move-in/out dates.
considerations: Timelines highlight key dates and events.
Gantt charts are good for tasks with start/end dates.

options.question: What is your ranking focus?

options.description: Sort bars by value to spotlight top or bottom items.
considerations: Use color to highlight top/bottom categories.
For large lists, add filter or search.

options.description: A compact way to show progress vs. a benchmark (e.g. revenue targets).
considerations: Include target marker and qualitative ranges if needed.
Great for KPI dashboards.

options.description: If you have many items, a sortable table can be more practical.
considerations: Enable search and column sorting.
Consider conditional formatting or color scales.

options.question: What geographic aspect are you visualizing?
Are you focusing on differences by region?

options.text: Yes, I'd like to compare regions or states
options.description: Color-code regions to show differences (e.g., occupancy rates by state).
considerations: Use a clear color scale for high-to-low values.
Consider drill-down for large maps.

options.text: No, I'd like exact facility locations
options.description: Markers placed at each location. Marker size/color can represent key metrics.
considerations: If points are dense, consider clustering or a heatmap layer.
Tooltip on hover can show facility details.

options.question: How many points or addresses are plotted?

options.description: Each location can have a distinct marker with labels/pop-ups.
considerations: Useful for highlighting specific sites or residences.
Watch out for privacy issues if showing exact addresses.

options.description: Group overlapping points or use density shading to reveal hotspots.
considerations: Allow zooming for more detail in dense areas.
Color gradients can help interpret data intensity.
